Populations in the boreal forest fluctuate according to a 10-year cycle, where their densities may vary 100-fold over the span of several years. Southern populations may be noncyclic or fluctuate with reduced amplitude (Krebs and Murray 2018, Krebs et al. Boutin 2018). This extreme local fluctuation in density makes it difficult to portray a single population level for Snowshoe Hares.

Some evidence supports contractions across the southern range periphery (Diefenbach et al. 2016, Sultaire et al. 2016). This may be related to habitat loss and increases in generalized predator (especially Coyote Canis latrans) numbers. Climate change is also likely to affect hare distribution and abundance, as decreasing snow duration increases camouflage mismatch of winter white hares on brown snowless backgrounds which in turn increases predation-induced mortality (Mills et al. 2013, Zimova et al. 2016).
range: The Snowshoe Hare appears in boreal and mixed deciduous forests of North America. It occurs in all provinces of Canada, except Nunavut. In the USA it is present in Alaska, as well as the western mountain states of Oregon, Washington, Nevada, Idaho, Montana, Wyoming, North and South Dakota, and Colorado, and small pockets in high elevation areas in New Mexico, Utah, and California. Its distribution also includes the Great Lakes region and eastern states of Pennsylvania, New York, Maine, Vermont, Rhode Island, Wisconsin, Michigan, Minnesota, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, and West Virginia. Population contractions have been described for populations in Wisconsin (Sultaire et al. 2016), in Pennsylvania, and the southeast (Diefenbach et al. 2016). Historic populations in the mountains of North Carolina, Tennessee, and Virginia, are largely extirpated, with West Virginia now the southern range limit.
useTrade: 5% of the total population is utilized. It is modestly used for food, and to a small extent the fur is used by natives. Historically, it was utilized heavily by trappers for the Hudson Bay Company.
conservationActions:
In some states in the southern parts of the range, hunting has been closed either temporarily or permanently to try to restore populations. The efficacy of such efforts usually has not been monitored carefully. In some cases hares have been stocked in an attempt to bolster the populations. This method also seems to have limited utility because captive-bred hares are highly vulnerable to predation and transplanted wild hares often succumb to death in captivity during transport. Conservation and management efforts have been recommended for the New Mexico extent of Snowshoe Hares, stemming from the restricted distribution and low abundance (Frey and Malaney 2006).

Snowshoe Hares are known to occur in the following U.S. National Wildlife Refuges (NWR):
Tetlin NWR (as of 2003)
Sherburne NWR
Seney NWR (as of 2004, reported as abundant)
Innoko NWR
Koyukuk NWR
Red Rock Lakes NWR (found in forested areas)
Kodiak NWR (as of 2006, reported as common)
Alaskan Peninsula/Becharof NWR (as of 2003)
Rachel Carson NWR (as of 2001, reported as common)
Silvio O. Conte NWR

rationale: The Arctic Hare is a widespread species. Populations seem to be healthy, overall, although there seems to be little monitoring occurring at the moment. The species is confirmed Least Concern.
habitat: The Arctic Hare requires tundra habitat lacking tree cover. Home range for this species is variable, ranging from 9-290 ha (Murray 2003). The Arctic Hare is a ground-dwelling species, but will utilize natural shelters or create small dens in the snow to regulate body temperatures (Gray 1993). This species is omnivorous, but it derives the bulk of its nutritional requirements from woody plants (Best and Henry 1994). There is uncertainty regarding the breeding season (Best and Henry 1994). The season may extend from April to mid-September, as inferred from male gonad enlargement (Best and Henry 1994). Arctic Hares are an important prey species for native carnivores.
threats: Southern populations may be subject to habitat loss, perhaps climate change as well, although this is speculative.
population: Populations of Arctic Hares are inexplicably patchy throughout the range of the species; vast regions may have no hares at all, and numbers appear to fluctuate from year to year. Reported densities vary from 0.2/ha to 15/ha, and in some localities they may be found in dense herds (Schai-Braun and Hackländer 2018). However, little to no monitoring of populations is ongoing.
range: The geographic range of the Arctic Hare consists of arctic tundra of Northwest Territories, and Nunavut, including Arctic islands, and western Newfoundland (Schai-Braun and Hackländer 2018). The Arctic Hare is also located along the coastal regions of Greenland where ice is not present (Parker 1977). It also occurs in northern Quebec and a small portion of northern Manitoba, along Hudson Bay. The southern range periphery borders with the tree line, although some Arctic Hares may move into the tree line during winter.
useTrade: Five percent of the total population is utilized. It is modestly used for food, and to a small extent the fur is used by local people.
conservationActions: Some jurisdictions have established seasonal limits on Arctic Hare harvest, but for the most part there are no restrictions due to the fact that most of the harvest is probably by First Nation inhabitants.

rationale: The Japanese Hare is considered common across much of it geographic range (Honshu, Shikoku, and Kyushu) and confirmed Least Concern. There is recent concern regarding density declines, and therefore efforts should be made to determine population status. The population on Sado Island, L. b. lyoni, is listed as the Near Threatened in the Japanese Red List (2007).
habitat:
The Japanese Hare occupies forests to grasslands from lowlands to subalpine zone, though they are more common from low montane and montane zones (Abe et al. 2005, Yamada 2018). Japanese Hares prefer open fields and edges of forests. Artificial conifer forests with ages of 40 – 50 years provide insufficient food and cover for Japanese Hares, and thus reduce hare density. The home range size varies from 10 – 30 ha, and hares can move distances of over 1 km at night (Yamada 2018).

The Japanese Hare breeds three to five times in a year, with one to four offspring per litter. Females reach sexual maturity at 10 months and their breeding season is from February to July (Flux and Angermann 1990). It is a nocturnal species (Flux and Angermann 1990).
threats: There are no major threats, but the population on Sado Island is declining due to predation by introduced Japanese martens (introduced because the Japanese Hare was girdling trees in forest plantations) (Shimizu and Shimano 2010). The population on Sado Island, L. b. lyoni, is listed as the Near Threatened in the Japanese Red List revised in 2007 (Yamada 2014).
population:
The Japanese Hare is common on Honshu, Shikoku and Kyushu; rare on Sado Island (where it used to be common).

Total population size in Japan is unknown; however, recent density became very low compared with those in 1970-80s when most forests were logged and urbanization (Saito et al. 2016). Fecal pellet counts indicated that population densities are likely to be higher in younger stands, where open canopy allows for greater herbaceous content (Shimano et al. 2006).

Population size only in forests (505,000 ha in total size) in Niigata prefecture in 2002-2003 was estimated as 140,000 hares. Density of L. b. angustidens was estimated to be 0.4/ha on Honshu (Hayashi 1978).
range: The Japanese Hare is endemic to Honshu, Shikoku, Kyushu, Sado Island, Oki Islands (Dogo, Nishinoshima), Awaji Island, Shodo Island, Goto Islands (Fukue, Nakadori), Amakusa Islands (Shimojima), Shimokoshiki Island.
useTrade: The Japanese Hare is an important game species in Japan (Flux and Angermann 1990, Yamada 2018).
conservationActions: Recent declines in density require the implementation of research actions to determine population trends, numbers and range. It is also recommended habitat and site-based actions be undertaken with emphasis on maintenance and conservation. In areas where density declines have been recorded recovery management should be employed.

rationale: The Black-tailed Jackrabbit is a widespread species. As such it does not qualify for threatened status under current criteria and it is confirmed Least Concern. However, a recent survey of long-term harvest information based on data from all western United States state game and fish agencies indicated a consistent downward trend in the numbers of most western United States (primarily Black-tailed and White-tailed Jackrabbits)—these species are not separated in agency databases, but the Black-tailed Jackrabbit is a major component of these databases (Brown et al. 2018). This downward trend is thought to be attributable to long term drought, habitat changes and the cessation of predator control activities. Numbers of this species are not prone to cycles as has been previously reported (Simes et al. 2015).
habitat:
The Black-tailed Jackrabbit is capable of inhabiting many types of habitat (Flinders and Chapman 2003, Beever et al. 2018). This species is positively associated, in terms of abundance and distribution, with grazing by domestic livestock (Flinders and Chapman 2003s, Brown et al. 2018). Diet is also variable for this species, dependent upon vegetation availability and location (Flinders and Chapman 2003, Beever et al. 2018). Generally, grasses and forbs are selected during the summer, while shrubs are chosen during winter months (Flinders and Chapman 2003). Variability in home range size is due to multiple factors like cover, predators, and competition (Flinders and Chapman 2003). Black-tailed Jackrabbits exhibit a crepuscular feeding behavior (Flinders and Chapman 2003, Beever et al. 2018). The breeding season is variable, contingent on latitude and environmental factors (Flinders and Chapman 2003). In Idaho the season is restricted to February to May (French et al. 1965). Where distribution occurs at lower latitudes the breeding season extends, in the southwestern USA it may last from early January to September (Griffing and Davis 1976).

The Magdalena Island Black-tailed Jackrabbit (L. c. magdalenae) is restricted to Margarita and Magdalena islands where its habitat consists of xeric scrubland, halophyte vegetation, mainly in the coastal dune areas and some smaller areas covered by mangroves. The predominant plant species recorded in the habitat of this subspecies are the Desert Limberbush (Jatropha cuneata), Adam’s Tree (Fouquieria diguetii), Yellow Daisy (Euphorbia margaritae), Goatnut (Simmondsia chinensis), Red Sand Verbina (Abronia maritima), Pincushion (Cochemiea halei), Strawberry Hedgehog (Echinocereus brandegeei), Ragweed (Ambrosia magdalenae), California Threeawn (Aristida californica), Sweet Mangrove (Maytenus phillanthoides), and Satin Milkvetch (Astragalus magdalenae var. magdalenae) as well as some herbaceous plants in the families Poaceae and Asteraceae (Lorenzo et al. 2014, 2018). Lepus c. magdalenae shares its habitat with several endemic rodents such as Chaetodipus arenarius albulus, C. spinatus magdalenae, Peromyscus eva, Peromyscus maniculatus magdalenae, Neotoma bryanti bryanti and Thomomys nigricans anitae and some birds such as the Northern Crested Caracara (Caracara cheriway) and reptiles such as the rattlesnake (Crotalus spp., Lorenzo et al. 2014, 2018).

The predominant vegetation of the Carmen Island Black-tailed Jackrabbit (L. c. sheldoni) habitat is xeric scrubland, with some areas covered by halophyte vegetation in coastal sand dunes and mangrove, interspersed with semi-open areas, plains, and rocky soil. Within the predominant plant species in the habitat are Velvet Mesquite (Prosopis articulata), Adam’s Tree (Fouquieria diguetii), Elephant Tree (Bursera microphylla), Ironwood (Olneya tesota), Euphorbia magdalenae, Glasswort (Arthrocnemum subterminale) and Desert Limberbush (Jatropha cuneata) (Lorenzo et al. 2014, 2018).
The Carmen Island Black-tailed Jackrabbit (L. c. sheldoni) shares its range with other terrestrial mammals as Bryant's Woodrat (Neotoma bryanti bryanti), Eva's Desert Mouse (Peromyscus eva carmeni), and the Spiny Pocket Mouse (Chaetodipus spinatus occultus), as well as the endemic Monserrat Chuckwalla (Sauromalus slevini), Cnemidophorus carmensis, and Western Blind Snake (Leptotyphlops humilis lindsayi) and the Baja California Rattlesnake (Crotalus enyo enyo) (Lorenzo et al. 2014, 2018).
threats:
Black-tailed Jackrabbits are not at risk from hunting for sport and local subsistence, but the effects of human perturbation and exotic predation are unknown. In some places competition with livestock, habitat fragmentation and human-induced fire represent important threats to populations. Declining habitat quality and climate change may also be affecting populations. Decreasing control of Coyotes (Canis latrans), Bobcats (Lynx rufus), and other predators has led to an increase in predation on this species.

The Magdalena Island Black-tailed Jackrabbit (L. c. magdalenae) shares its habitat with predators such as Coyotes (Canis latrans peninsulae) with an average population density estimated of 0.73 individuals/km² and a number estimated of 230 individuals on the island, which may be negatively affecting the endemic populations of this subspecies. On the Margarita Island, Goats (Capra aegagrus) and several Feral Cats and their traces (footprints and excreta, Felis sylvestris) were obsered in the habitat of L. c. magdalenae, as well as also nests of Osprey (Pandion haliaetus). The high density of Feral Cats represents competing exotic fauna that can affect the endemic populations of the jackrabbits on the island (Lorenzo et al. 2014, 2018).
The Carmen Island Black-tailed Jackrabbit (L. c. sheldoni) also shares its range with a high density of Feral Cats, which may be affecting the population of the island's endemic subspecies (Lorenzo et al. 2014, 2018).
population: Population density can vary widely from 0.1-1.2 animals/ha in natural habitats, to 1.5-208/ha on adjacent agricultural land (Beever et al. 2018). In 2009 and 2010 the population density of L. c. magdalenae on Magdalena Island was estimated to be 15.3 individuals/km² and the total number of individuals was estimated at 4,804 in an area of 314 km². For the same subspecies on Margarita Island, the population density estimated in 2010 was 1.05 individuals/km² and the number of individuals was estimated to be 250 in an area of 238.5 km². In 2009 and 2011 the population density of L. c. sheldoni was estimated to be 9.8 individuals/km² with and estimated population of 926 in an area of 94.6 km² (Lorenzo et al. 2014, 2018). Populations have also been noted to vary significantly over time. For example, the reported harvest of jackrabbits in California in 1964 was over 3,000,000 – a value that has declined to less than 100,000/year since 1997 (Brown et al. 2018). These trend data are mirrored in several western states in the USA (Brown et al. 2018).
range: The Black-tailed Jackrabbit is widely distributed across Mexico and the USA (Flinders and Chapman 2003, Beever et al. 2018). Its range in Mexico includes the states of Hidalgo, Queretaro, northern Guanajuato, San Luis Potosi, eastern Tamaulipas, Zacatecas, Aguascalientes, eastern Durango, Chihuahua (excluding the southwest region), the extreme northeast region of Jalisco, Coahuila, Nuevo Leon, northern Sonora, and the entire Baja peninsula (Flinders and Chapman 2003). It is absent from Tiburon and La Guardia islands. Several forms are found on islands: L. c. sheldoni on Carmen Island (243 km²) and L. c. xanti on Cerralvo Island (140 km²) in the Gulf of California, and L. c. magdalenae on Magdalena and Margarita islands (314 km² and 238 km², respectively) in the Pacific Ocean (in addition to being found on the mainland) (Lorenzo et al. 2014, 2018). In the USA its range includes Texas, New Mexico, Arizona, Nevada, eastern Colorado, Nebraska, Kansas, most of Oklahoma including an isolated population in eastern section of the state, Utah (excluding the northeast), California (excluding part of the central region), most of Oregon (excluding western and central regions), southeast Washington, southern Idaho, an isolated population in Montana, and the extreme western region and southeast portion of Wyoming, it is no longer found in western Missouri (Flinders and Chapman 2003). The Black-tailed Jackrabbit has been successfully introduced into Massachusetts, Maryland, New Jersey, Virginia and southern Florida (Flinders and Chapman 2003). It has also recently colonized Cerralvo Island in the Gulf of California (Lorenzo et al. 2010, Beever et al. 2018).
useTrade: Popular game animal.
conservationActions: The following conservation measures are recommended for the Black-tailed Jackrabbit: research in monitoring/trends and species-based action regarding harvest management. Long-term research is recommended with regard to ecological relationships and population dynamics and genetics. There is also a need for more definitive classification of jackrabbit subspecies. Furthermore, data are needed to determine gaps in distribution and relationship dynamics between Black-tailed Jackrabbits and other jackrabbits that occur sympatrically. For island populations of the Black-tailed Jackrabbit: research in continuous monitoring of populations of jackrabbits as well as the exotic and introduced mammal species. L. c. magdalenae and L. c. sheldoni are protected as subject to special protection by the Mexican government in the Mexican Official Norm 059 (SEMARNAT 2010).

rationale: The European Hare is confirmed Least Concern; it is widespread and abundant across its geographic range (Flux and Angermann 1990, Schai-Braun and Hackländer 2016, Hackländer and Schai-Braun 2018). There is evidence of population declines beginning in the early 20th century in association with the intensification of agricultural practices (Hackländer and Schai-Braun 2018). It is listed under Appendix III of the Bern Convention in Europe (as “Lepus capensis (europaeus)” Council of Europe 1979). Several European countries have placed the European Hare on their Red List as "Near Threatened" or "Threatened" (Reichlin et al. 2006). There is increasing concern regarding the status of regional forms of this species (Schai-Braun and Hackländer 2016). However, the status in Europe and the European Union is “Least Concern” (Temple and Terry 2007).
habitat:
The European Hare is a highly adaptable species that can persist in numerous habitat types from sea level to alpine areas (Hackländer and Schai-Braun 2018). There is a positive association with hare abundance and habitat diversity (Smith, Jennings and Harris 2005). Various surveys have investigated habitat preferences of European Hares. As the study areas vary considerably, the results diverge also substantially. However, fallow land is preferred consistently in all studies, whereas residential areas are avoided (Schai-Braun et al. 2013, Schai-Braun and Hackländer 2016). When available, weeds and wild grasses are selected by the European Hare, however, intensified agro-practices have reduced this food source resulting in the selection of crop species (Reichlin, Klansek and Hackländer 2006, Schai-Braun et al. 2015).

The European Hare averages three litters/yr, but can vary from one to five litters/yr (Schai-Braun and Hackländer 2016). Litter size can vary with respect to the season, smaller litters produced earlier in the season and larger litters later (Schai-Braun and Hackländer 2018). The birth weight of the European Hare is approximately 100 g (Hackländer and Schai-Braun 2018). Gestation is 42 days and reproduction occurs year round in suitable habitats. In northern ranges or higher altitude reproduction is restricted to summer (Hackländer and Schai-Braun 2018). Physiological age is 8-12 years (Hackländer and Schai-Braun 2018). Females reach maturity around 4-5 months Hackländer and Schai-Braun 2018).
threats:
A study reviewing available literature regarding population densities in connection with habitat that was identified as primarily farmland from 12 European countries, concluded that the primary cause of the European Hare decline was intensification of agriculture (Smith et al. 2005). It is inferred that this threat is pertinent to the species across its geographic range where farming is practiced. Smith et al. (2005) also identified negative associations with predation and precipitation in respect to abundance. However, "field size, temperature, precipitation, and hunting had no effect on density throughout Europe" (Smith et al. 2005). In Greece, Spain, France and Denmark, the restocking of hares from other regions or countries to complement hare densities for hunting has been identified as a threat to regional gene pools (Mamuris et al. 2001, Schai-Braun and Hackländer 2016). This issue has also been identified as a concern for the Cantabric population in Spain (Palacios et al. 2004). Disease is an additional threat to the European Hare and several have been identified as the principle sources of mortality (Lamarque, Barrat and Moutou 1996). These diseases are European Brown Hare Syndrome (EBHS), Pasteurellosis, Yersiniosis (Pseudo-tuberculosis), Coccidiosis and Tularaemia (Lamarque et al. 1996, Lavazza and Cooke 2018).

Genetic diversity of the European Hare in the North Rhine-Westphalia region of Germany indicates that hare populations still retain sufficient diversity (Fickel et al. 2005). However, it is cautioned that restricted gene flow could eventually lead to allelic fixation and inbreeding depression within populations that become isolated (Fickel et al. 2005).
population:
Populations of the European Hare have been experiencing declines in many areas across its geographic range in Europe (Hackländer and Schai-Braun 2018). Natural population densities are about 2/100 ha, but can reach up to 275/100 ha in highly suitable habitats (Hackländer and Schai-Braun 2016).

A study conducted in the Czech Republic found mean hare densities were highest in habitat with the following characteristics (Pikula et al. 2004): elevation (sea level up to 200 m); annual snow cover duration (40-60 days); mean annual precipitation (450-700 mm); annual sunshine duration (1801-2000 hrs); mean annual air temperature (>10˚C).

Population dynamics are mainly affected by juvenile mortality due to annual differences in weather conditions, mechanical activities in agricultural land, diseases, and predation (Hackländer and Schai-Braun 2018).
range: The current Eurasian distribution of the European Hare extends from the  northern provinces of Spain, to introduced populations in the United  Kingdom and southern regions of Scandinavia, south to northern portions  of the Middle East, and has naturally expanded east to sections of  Siberia. The south-eastern boundary of its range runs from the southern  Caspian Sea south to the Persian Gulf (Flux and Angermann 1990,  Schai-Braun and Hackländer 2016, Hackländer and Schai-Braun 2018). This  species has been introduced as a game species extensively to countries  across the globe, including eastern Australia, New Zealand, South  America up to 28°S, Canada, and the United States (Great Lakes Area), as  well as numerous islands in the Indian and Atlantic Ocean (Hackländer  and Schai-Braun 2018). This species can be found at elevations ranging  from sea level up to 2,400 m (Schai-Braun and Hackländer 2016).
useTrade: The European Hare is recognized as an important game species  throughout its historical distribution, including those areas where it  has been introduced (Flux and Angermann 1990, Schai-Braun and Hackländer  2016, Hackländer and Schai-Braun 2018).
conservationActions:
The European Hare is recognized as an important game species throughout its distribution and as such conservation measures are required to halt declining populations (Flux and Angermann 1990). The recent decline of this species has garnered it protection under the Bern Convention as an Appendix III listing (Council of Europe 1979). In Norway, Germany, Austria and Switzerland, population declines have resulted in country-specific Red Listing as "near threatened" or "threatened" (Reichlin et al. 2006).

Research is needed to determine population dynamics specific to habitat type and the effects habitat change has on life history parameters with regard to declines (Smith et al. 2005). There is a lack of understanding as to why hare numbers are low in pastoral landscapes and therefore, research should be conducted within this habitat type with particular emphasis paid to demography and behavioral ecology (Smith et al. 2005).When population declines are the direct result of agricultural intensification, which results in increased application of fertilizer, landscape homogeneity and mechanization, population declines of the European Hare can be countered by augmenting habitat to boost heterogeneity (Smith et al. 2005).

In Spain, molecular phylogenetic studies have shown that the Cantabric population has unique mtDNA in relation to other European populations (Palacios et al. 2004). As an important hunting species, declining numbers have prompted the importation of non-Iberian hares (from France and elsewhere) to supplement hare densities (Palacios et al. 2004). In an effort to conserve this population's gene pool, a captive breeding program has been implemented (Palacios et al. 2004). As of 2003 this program has successfully bred leverets and in 2004 turned its focus to increasing genetic variability by introducing individuals from new localities (Palacios et al. 2004).

rationale: This is a widespread species that is characterized as very common. Although the species is subject to habitat destruction, intensive hunting and predation, it is confirmed as Least Concern because it is unlikely to be declining at nearly the rate required to qualify for listing in a threatened category.
habitat:
The Indian Hare can be found in wide variety of habitats such as short grasslands, barren agricultural fields, crop fields, and forest roads. The species can be seen in forests of many types other than the mangroves and tall grassland habitats. However, one can see the species adjacent to forest areas in agricultural fields. Its diet consists primarily of grasses (Schai-Braun and Hackländer 2016, Molur and Nameer 2018).

It breeds throughout the year, but the peak breeding season is during the monsoon season (Flux and Angermann 1990). Litter size is one to four, but can be higher (Gurung and Singh 1996). Forbs and grasses constitute the bulk of their diet (Flux and Angermann 1990). The Indian Hare is characterized as a shy species (Gurung and Singh 1996). It exhibits activity during crepuscular and nocturnal hours (Chakraborty et al. 2005).
threats: Major threats for the Indian Hare include habitat destruction and conversion of prime forest areas for agricultural purposes, as well as intensive hunting by locals for meat. Individual hares, especially the young ones living in the forest areas, are subjected to predation by carnivorous mammals and birds. The Indian Hare is also threatened by domestic predators, competition from livestock, and human set forest fires (Chakraborty et al. 2005).
population: The Indian Hare appears to be very common wherever they occur. However,  the population in India is subjected to severe fragmentation due to  expanding agricultural fields and pressure on forest in terms of fuel  wood collection and sometimes illegal hunting.
range:
The Indian Hare is distributed throughout India, except the high reaches of the Himalayas and mangrove areas within the Sundarbans in the state of West Bengal. The geographic distribution extends into eastern Pakistan, southern Nepal, Sri Lanka, and Bangladesh excluding the Sundarbans (Flux and Angermann 1990, Molur and Nameer 2018). It is thought to occur in Bhutan as well, but exact locations are not known (Chakraborty et al. 2005). This species can be found at elevations ranging from 50-4,500 m (Chakraborty et al. 2005).

This species has been introduced (as a single or several unidentified subspecies) to many islands Comoro, Mayotte, Madagascar, Réunion (including Gunners Quoin I), Mauritius (Alaléga Island), Seychelles (Cousin I), and Andaman Island in the Indian Ocean, and into New Guinea. The Gunners Quoin population of the Indian Hare has been eradicated (Schai-Braun and Hackländer 2016). The Indian Hare has been considered native to Java by McNeely (1981), but its origin there has been considered uncertain by Hoffmann and Smith (2005).
useTrade: Up to 40% of some populations of the Indian Hare are utilized. This  species is hunted for meat, but is also removed to prevent crop damage  (Flux and Angermann 1990).
conservationActions:
This species is listed under the Schedule IV of the Indian Wildlife (Protection) Act, 1972. No specific conservation action has been framed to protect the species in the wild in India. However, a number of individuals are present within sanctuaries and national parks and are somewhat protected from human intervention. Further taxonomic research is needed for this species, as well as increased public awareness (Chakraborty et al. 2005).

The Indian Hare may be impacted from habitat fragmentation, habitat destruction (conversion of prime habitat to cultivated land), predation by non-native animals, competition with livestock, and human-induced fires.

rationale: The White-tailed Jackrabbit is a widespread species, confirmed as Least Concern. Population status across its entire distribution is not currently known, but non-trivial declines have been observed over the past 150 years across much of its range (Brown et al. 2018). This cold-tolerant jackrabbit is now rare or extinct in portions of its former range in British Columbia, Colorado, Kansas, Nebraska, South Dakota, Iowa, Minnesota, Wisconsin, Missouri, and Washington (Applegate 1997, Brown et al. 2018). It is a species of concern in California (Williams 1986), and was reported to be absent from former habitats in the Yellowstone ecosystem (Berger et al. 2005, Berger 2008) - a status shown to be overly pessimistic by Gunther et al. (2009). The cause of this reduction is generally thought to center on the conversion of native prairie to shrub-steppe or agriculture and/or the arrival of expanding Black-tailed Jackrabbit populations better suited to human disturbance (Brown et al. 2018). It is unknown whether these declines and replacement by Black-tailed Jackrabbits have been the result of habitat changes or reflect a continuation of climatic shifts that have occurred throughout Holocene times (Brown et al. 2018). Therefore this species is declining and is clearly a species that should be carefully watched.
habitat: The primary habitat of the White-tailed Jackrabbit is open prairie and plains grassland, but this varies with locality (Flux and Angermann 1990, Beever et al. 2018). They are also found on montane and subalpine pastures among scattered evergreens to 3,100 m altitude in Colorado (Flux and Angermann 1990). Diet of this species is predominantly grasses and forbs, with shrubs during the winter (Lim 1987). The breeding season was recorded to extend from late February through mid-July in North Dakota (Flux and Angermann 1990). A similar breeding season was recorded in Wyoming (Rogowitz 1992). The season is shortened in the northern extent of its range to May through early July (Lim 1987). The gestation period is variable, one account sets it as low as one month and another as high as 43 days (Lim 1987). It is thought that elevation and latitude may influence total gestation time (Lim 1987). Breeding conditions and environmental factors influence the total number of litters produced each year (Lim 1987). Common litter size is recorded as four to five young. Longevity is unknown but speculated to be up to five years (Forsyth 1999).
threats: There are numerous hypothesized factors contributing to the decline of the White-tailed Jackrabbit, but the most prevalent appears to be the conversion of native prairie to shrub-steppe or non-grass agriculture. This habitat alteration has led to the exclusion of White-tailed Jackrabbits where the distribution expansion of Black-tailed Jackrabbits has occurred (Lim 1987, Brown et al. 2018).
population: The population density of White-tailed Jackrabbits varies greatly temporally and across the range of the species. In the shortgrass prairie region it has been reported at a density of 2.2 per square km, but densities as high as 43 – 71/km² have been recorded in Minnesota and Iowa, respectively (Beever et al. 2018).
range: The White-tailed Jackrabbit has a wide geographic distribution. Its historic distribution extended across the southern regions of Canada, including south-central British Columbia, Alberta and Saskatchewan, southwestern Manitoba and the extreme southwest of Ontario (Flux and Angermann 1990, Beever et al. 2018). The distribution within the USA included: Washington, Oregon, California, Nevada, Idaho, Montana, Wyoming, Utah, Colorado, New Mexico, Nebraska, Kansas, North and South Dakota, Minnesota, Wisconsin, Iowa, Missouri, and Illinois (Flux and Angermann 1990, Beever et al. 2018). This distribution represented an expansion from its original distribution, which resulted from the creation of suitable habitat (Lim 1987). There is some debate to whether this species was introduced to Wisconsin (Lim 1987). Now, however, the range of the species is definitely contracting. Some treatments indicate that this species has been possibly extirpated from British Columbia, southern Nebraska, Kansas and Illinois, and some recent distribution maps exclude Missouri (Flinders and Chapman 2003). The White-tailed Jackrabbit is excluded from some areas of its range resulting from the expansion of the Black-tailed Jackrabbit (Lim 1987). This species was recorded at an elevation of 4,319 m on Mt. Bross, Colorado (Lim 1987). Its lower limit is recorded as 30 m on the Columbian plains (Lim 1987).
useTrade: This species has been hunted for sport and their fur is sold to fur buyers and mink ranchers (Flux and Angermann 1990, Brown et al. 2018).
conservationActions:
Research should be conducted to ascertain the ecological role of this species within prairie and sage steppe ecosystems. Furthermore, efforts should be made to determine the species’ status, life-history, demography, and predator-prey relationships. Also this species be removed from the 'varmint' list produced by the State of Wyoming (Berger et al. 2006). More data are needed to understand the factors that operate when Black-tailed Jackrabbits and White-tailed Jackrabbits occur sympatrically (Flinders and Chapman 2003).

The White-tailed Jackrabbit is classified as “possibly extirpated” in Kansas, southern Nebraska, and British Columbia, “imperiled” in New Mexico, “vulnerable” in California, “apparently secure” in Colorado, Montana, Nebraska, Oregon, South Dakota, and Wyoming, and “secure” only in Idaho and Nevada. The White-tailed Jackrabbit is a priority species in Washington where it is a “species of greatest conservation need” (Ferguson and Atamian 2012, Brown et al. 2018).

rationale:
The Swamp Rabbit (Sylvilagus aquaticus) is a species with a wide distribution, and though the area of suitable habitat is declining in most areas due to human development of land, population viability analyses suggest long term persistence (Robinson et al. 2016). It occurs in many protected areas (U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service 2006). The species is confirmed Least Concern.

Swamp Rabbits are considered endangered in the state of Indiana and a species of special concern in Missouri and South Carolina (Indiana Department of Natural Resources 2017, Missouri Department of Conservation 2018, Nielsen and Berkman 2018).
habitat:
Swamp Rabbits occur in swampy, lowland, or river bottom areas, always near water (Chapman and Feldhamer 1981). They are always associated with water and will swim to escape predators and hunters (Whitaker and Hamilton 1998). In Illinois, bottomland hardwood forest habitat is preferred, as are areas of brushy habitat and canopy cover (Zollner, Smith and Brennan 2000a, Scharine et al. 2009, Scharine et al. 2011, Berkman et al. 2018). Use of early successional bottomland habitats suggests that restoration efforts could help maintain populations (Crawford et al. 2018). Because of their habitat preferences, Swamp Rabbits have been suggested as an indicator of quality bottomland forest habitat (Hillard et al. 2017). Despite their preference for lowlands, adjacent upland areas may provide important habitat during seasonal flooding (Vale and Kissell 2010). Radiotracking studies suggest that Swamp Rabbits avoid open areas, such as residential areas, agricultural areas, and roads (Crawford et al. 2018). Swamp Rabbit occupancy and detectability increase in larger tracts of habitat (Fantz et al. 2017). In timber habitat Swamp Rabbit density is around 2 rabbits/ha (Nielsen and Berkman 2018).

Swamp Rabbits prefer a diet of sedges and also feed on grasses and forbs (Chapman and Ceballos 1990).

Females have litter sizes from one to six, and produce two to five litters per year (Chapman and Ceballos 1990). Gestation is 35-40 days (Whitaker and Hamilton 1998) and females reach sexual maturity at 152 days of age.
threats:
Swamp Rabbits are a favorite game species, though their speed, ability to swim, and habitat preferences offers some protection from hunters and predators (Whitaker and Hamilton 1998). Hunting is regulated by individual state wildlife agencies (Chapman and Ceballos 1990). While hunting is not a major threat to stable populations (Nielsen and Berkman 2018), Swamp Rabbits appear to have a sensitivity to harvest in the late season (winter) (Bond et al. 2004). Population viability modeling suggests that changes in fecundity and catastrophic flooding may pose the greatest risk to the species (Robinson et al. 2016).

Habitat loss has been the greatest cause of decline of Swamp Rabbits. In Missouri in 1973, a decline of suitable habitat from 850,000 ha to 40,000 ha was recorded over the previous 103 years (Korte and Fredrickson 1977). The habitat was converted from forest to cropland. Changes to waterways and resulting flooding also negatively impact the availability of habitat for Swamp Rabbits (Nielsen and Berkman 2018).

Habitat fragmentation is an issue associated with human encroachment upon Swamp Rabbit habitat. Many Swamp Rabbit populations exist on small tracts of private property, impeding dispersal and creating difficulties for management (Scheibe and Henson 2003).

Flooding of wet forested areas has a negative impact on Swamp Rabbit populations, but floods in some areas induce dispersal (Scheibe and Henson 2003).
population:
Swamp Rabbits are an important game species in much of their range and are hunted for meat, fur, and sport. They are known to be locally abundant in some areas but appear to be declining in others (Chapman and Ceballos 1990, Barbour et al. 2001, Scheibe and Henson 2003). Few studies have been conducted to determine the abundance or decline of Swamp Rabbits.

In Missouri, the overall area of suitable habitat is decreasing, but there are still several viable populations within the known range, and there is some indication that new populations have recently been naturally established, possibly due to dispersal facilitated by flooding (Scheibe and Henson 2003). In Louisiana, there are large tracts of suitable habitat and it is an important game species (Chapman and Ceballos 1990).

In South Carolina, the Rabbit Hunter Survey data from 2016-2017 show that there is an increase in rabbits jumped/hour, 1.35 (2007-2008) to 1.58 (2016-2017), but of the rabbits harvested only 1.72% were Swamp Rabbits (South Carolina Rabbit Hunter Survey, 2016-2017).

Three population viability analyses (PVA) have provided insight into local population trends of Swamp Rabbits at the northern fringe of their range. In southern Illinois, the PVA suggested a 0% chance of quasi-extinction (90% metapopulation decline) of Swamp Rabbits within 25 (or even 50) years. Changes in fecundity values and the effects of catastrophic flooding had the greatest effect on extinction risk, and changes in no other parameter yielded any appreciable impact. Removing the largest patches from the population increased the 25-year risk of extinction to 4%, whereas any other modifications to the habitat did not change the extinction risk (Robinson et al. 2016). Roy Nielsen et al. (2008) found southern Indiana Swamp Rabbits existed as a metapopulation that appeared to be stable. Metapopulation dynamics were best characterized as being stationary, but habitat area was an important factor in extinction rates, occupied patches were significantly larger than unoccupied patches. In Missouri, more than 50% of available habitat patches were predicted to contain rabbits after 1000 years, both patch area and patch isolation were significantly related to patch occupancy and play key roles in the incidence of Swamp Rabbits (Pajda-De La O et al. 2013).
range:
Swamp Rabbits occur in the southeastern United States in eastern Texas and Oklahoma, most of Arkansas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, the western tip of the Florida panhandle, western Georgia, western Tennessee, far western Kentucky, the northwestern tip of South Carolina, the southwestern tip of North Carolina, far southern Illinois, southwestern Indiana, and the south sections of Missouri (Nielsen and Berkman 2018).

There are two recognized subspecies of Swamp Rabbits: S. a. littoralis, which occurs in a narrow fragment of habitat along the southern gulf coastal from Mississippi to Texas, and S. a. aquaticus, which occupies the northern section of the range and is more common in dense forest (Chapman and Feldhamer 1981, Chapman and Ceballos 1990).
useTrade: The species is hunted for sport, meat and fur.
conservationActions:
Hunting of Swamp Rabbits is managed individually by state wildlife agencies (Chapman and Ceballos 1990). Because Swamp Rabbits occurs in many instances on small tracts of private land, management becomes problematic (Scheibe and Henson 2003). Increasing the area of continuous tracts of suitable habitat may be key to Swamp Rabbit conservation (Scheibe and Henson 2003, Fantz et al. 2017).

Swamp Rabbits are currently found in three managed areas in Missouri: Mingo National Wildlife Refuge (NWR), Duck Creek Conservation Area, and Donaldson Point Conservation Area (Scheibe and Henson 2003). It also occurs in White River NWR in Arkansas, Panther Swamp NWR, Mathews Brake NWR, Hillside NWR, and Morgan Brake NWR in Mississippi, Atchafalaya NWR in Louisiana, Deep Fork NWR in Oklahoma, and Chickasaw NWR in Tennessee (U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service 2006).

rationale: The Desert Cottontail is confirmed as Least Concern, it is widespread and common, occurs in a large contiguous area, is a habitat and dietary generalist, and none of the subspecies are known to be significantly declining. However, a recent survey of long-term harvest information based on data from all western United States state game and fish agencies indicated a consistent downward trend in the numbers of all western United States cottontails (primarily S. floridanus, S. audubonii, S. nuttallii – these species tend not to be separated in agency databases, but the Desert Cottontail is a major component of these databases (Brown et al. 2018).
habitat:
The Desert Cottontail inhabits arid and mountain regions from woodlands, grasslands to deserts at low elevations (Chapman and Ceballos 1990, Laundré 2018). They appear to avoid midday heat and are active in the twilight hours of dawn and dusk as well as at night (Hoffmeister 1986). They prefer habitat with a high density of cover, rarely venturing out into more open areas (Laundré 2018).

The breeding season begins in December or January for a length of seven to nine months. Mean litter sizes vary among populations, between 2.6-3.6 young per litter, which is small for the genus (Chapman and Willner 1978).

The diet of the Desert Cottontail varies depending on habitat and cover. Forbs are the most dominant forage type, followed by grasses and then shrubs (Laundré 2018).

Early evidence indicated that the Desert Cottontail is short-lived and one study found that no rabbit lived past the age of 19 months, while most rabbits lived less than one year (Chapman and Willner 1978).
threats:
The Desert Cottontail is widespread and common in many parts of its range, including Mexico, but cattle grazing and habitat loss due to land clearing may affect some populations (Chapman and Ceballos 1990, Brown et al. 2018). Predation by invasive alien species, including domestic dogs and cats, presents a threat in some areas populated by humans (Chapman and Willner 1978).

The Desert Cottontail is hunted for sport and local subsistence and as an important game species it is managed by individual states in the USA, where it is not considered to be under threat (Brown et al. 2018).

Human-induced fire may represent a threat for some populations.
population:
Little specific data regarding population density and abundance exists, but the Desert Cottontail is known to be common throughout most of its range in Mexico and is not considered to be threatened by state game agencies in the USA (Brown et al. 2018). A report in 1947 showed that a population in the San Joaquin Experimental Range in California had a population density that fluctuated over three years (1939-41) of 4.7, 1.6, and 2.9 individuals per hectare (Chapman and Willner 1978). A study in northeastern Colorado showed a density of 16.3 individuals per hectare (Flinders and Hansen 1973).

In the Reserva de la Biosfera de Mapimi in Durango, Mexico, the Desert Cottontail population is declining (Portales 2004).
range:
The Desert Cottontail occurs in the western USA and north and central Mexico. In the USA the western boundary is the Pacific Ocean and in the east it barely extends into the Great Plains. The far northern extent of the range almost reaches Canada in eastern Montana and southwestern North Dakota, extending south through Wyoming, western South Dakota, Nebraska, and Kansas, the panhandle of Oklahoma, and western Texas. Except for extreme mountainous areas, the range includes Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona, south and central Utah, southern Nevada, and all but northern California (Laundré 2018). In Mexico, the range includes all of Baja California, Baja California Sur, most of Sonora and Chihuahua, Coahuila, Nuevo Leon, western Tamaulipas, San Luis Potosi, Zacatecas, Aguascalientes, eastern Durango, northern Sinaloa, north-eastern Jalisco, northern Guanajuato, northern Queretaro, central Hidalgo, Tlaxcala, north-central Puebla, and a small area in western Veracruz (Vargas Cuenca and Cervantes 2005).

The Desert Cottontail occurs from below sea level in Death Valley, California, to 1,800 m or higher (Chapman and Willner 1978, Laundré 2018).
useTrade: It is hunted for food and sport.
conservationActions: The Desert Cottontail is managed a game species in the USA by individual state wildlife agencies. None of the subspecies are known to be under threat and no new conservation measures are needed, although Brown et al. (2018) stress that habitat management plans to increase shrub cover are needed, as well as curtailing potential detrimental impacts of agricultural chemicals in the range of the species.

rationale: The Eastern Cottontail is confirmed as Least Concern; it is the most widely distributed species of Sylvilagus and is abundant throughout its range (Chapman, Hockman and Ojeda 1980, Nielsen and Berkman 2018). This species has been introduced in regions of North America and Europe, and is expanding its range by displacing other Leporids (Chapman and Ceballos 1990).
habitat:
The historical habitat of Eastern Cottontails was diverse, including deserts, swamps, glades, prairies, rain forests, boreal forests, hardwood forests, and woodlands (Chapman et al. 1980). In developed areas, they survive well in farmland, pasture, and hedgerows (Chapman and Ceballos 1990).

The diet of Eastern Cottontails is variable, depending on the type of habitat and the season, including woody plants in the dormant season and herbaceous plants in the growing season (Chapman et al. 1980). Breeding season varies depending on elevation and latitude, with breeding activity beginning later at higher elevations and northern latitudes (Chapman et al. 1980). Average gestation time is 28 days and size at birth ranges from 3.06-5.06 cm (Lorenzo and Cervantes 2005). Litter sizes are 3-5 with 3-4 litters per year (Lorenzo and Cervantes 2005). Total length ranges from 33.5-48.5 cm (Lorenzo and Cervantes 2005).
threats: Although abundant, subpopulations of Eastern Cottontails are at risk  human perturbation, habitat change, predation from invasive alien  species, and from hunting pressure (sport and local subsistence)  throughout its range. In some locations it is threatened by livestock  competition and habitat fragmentation.
population:
Eastern Cottontails are abundant, widespread, and highly effective colonizers. New populations of Eastern Cottontails have been successfully introduced outside their range, and in some cases, they have been known to displace native Leporids, including the New England Cottontail (Chapman and Ceballos 1990, Litvaitis et al. 2008, Nielsen and Berkman 2018). Peak densities have been recorded at 20 individuals/ha, but they are more commonly found in densities of less than 10/ha (Nielsen and Berkman 2018).

In Virginia, the population has declined over the past 50 years or so. This decline may be due to the loss of early successional habitat that is being turned into farmland and is exacerbated by an increase in the cottontail's predators. In most years, populations of adult cottontails experience 60-80% mortality, but mortality rates in some populations can be as high as 95% (Nielsen and Berkman 2018). However, in areas where there is good habitat there are still abundant populations (Virginia Department of Game and Inland Fisheries 2008).
range:
The Eastern Cottontail is widely distributed throughout the USA (eastern USA east of the Rocky Mountains, portions of southwest and northwest), Central America (central and eastern Mexico, southwestern Guatemala, southern Honduras, El Salvador, central Nicaragua, northwestern Costa Rica), and occurs in southern Canada (Saskatchewan, Manitoba, Ontario, and Quebec) and the northern part of South America (Colombia and Venezuela) (Nielsen and Berkman 2018).

Eastern Cottontails can survive in diverse habitats, allowing the range to spread quickly (Chapman and Ceballos 1990). They have more recently been introduced to Italy and other areas outside of their historical range (Nielsen and Berkman 2018).
useTrade: The species is hunted for food and sport hunting.
conservationActions:
The Eastern Cottontail is the most important regulated game animal in the USA. While Eastern Cottontails have declined since the mid 20th Century due to agricultural changes (Mankin and Warner 1999a,b), they have also been introduced widely outside their original range (Nielsen and Berkman 2018). They can present a threat to sympatric species, such as the New England Cottontail (S. transitionalis) in north-eastern USA (Chapman and Ceballos 1990, Litvaitis et al. 2008).

Research is needed regarding taxonomy, distribution, population size, and to determine how the Eastern Cottontail affects other species.

rationale: The Appalachian Cottontail is known to be a rare species and occurs in  patchy fragments throughout its range. It was listed on the IUCN Red  List of Threatened Species as NT – Near Threatened in 2008 (Barry and  Lazell 2008). The most robust populations are in West Virginia, where  habitat is decreasing due to enchroachment of exotic plants and habitat  conversion, out of the 21 localities known in the state only nine have had  documented sightings in the last 20 years (West Virginia Division of  Natural Resources). Across the southern poritions of the range (Alabama  and Georgia) the species is considered to be critically imperiled due to  loss of habitat and is known from fewer than five localities in either  state (Alabama Department of Conservation and Natural Resources. 2015,  Georgia Biodiversity Portal). Across the range the Appalachian  Cottontail thought to be declining, but because of the lack of data  regarding the status of populations of this species it is difficult to  assess how severe that decline is, but at least a 25-30% in the last ten  years is suspected. In light of this uncertainty, a change of status  from Near Threatened to Vulnerable A2ce is not justified at this time,  and new surveys on the status of this species are necessary (Barry  2018).
habitat:
The Appalachian Cottontail is found at high elevations with conifers and ericaceous species in the central to southern Appalachian Mountains, mixed oak forests and early successional (recent clearcut) habitats with dense, ericaceous vegetation (Bunch et al. 1997, Chapman 1999) or blackberry thickets (Bunch et al. 1997). They have also been recorded from old growth forest with dense understory (Bunch et al. 1997, Bunch and Dye 1999). Dense understory that provides concealment and thermal cover is important (Laseter 1999). Individuals also have been observed near openings in rocky outcrops (Barry 2018).

Appalachian Cottontails have been found in a patchy distribution across western North Carolina. In locations where Eastern Cottontails are present, preliminary data suggest the Appalachian Cottontail is less widespread, possibly due to competitive exclusion. Surveys in 2018 documented the species at elevations ranging from 1000 to 1800 m in varied habitats, including spruce-fir forest, northern hardwood forest, oak forest, cove forest, and shrub-dominated balds (Leisl Erb, pers. comm.).

They feed on ferns, grasses, forbs, shrubs, and, unique among cottontails, conifer needles (Chapman 1999). Early March through early September is the breeding season for this species, and breeding is synchronous (Chapman 1999, Barry 2018). Gestation is 28 days and an average of 24 young/female are born annually (Chapman 1999).
threats:
Threats to the Appalachian Cottontail include:
  1. Destruction, fragmentation, and maturation of habitat (Barbour and Litvaitis 1993).
  2. Urban and suburban development.
  3. Indirect encroachment on habitat by Eastern Cottontails (S. floridanus), which thrive better in developed areas and require less cover than Appalachian Cottontails (Barbour and Litvaitis 1993).
  4. Indiscriminate hunting may result from lack of knowledge by sportsmen or because Appalachian Cottontails are phenotypically similar to Eastern Cottontails (Chapman 1999).
  5. Lack of education on existence, biology, and habitat requirements of this species.
population: Appalachian Cottontail populations are highly fragmented, and in much of the range the species is considered rare, except in portions of eastern Tennessee and the Monongahela National Forest in West Virginia (Laseter 1999), and western North Carolina (www.dpr.ncparks.gov/mammals/view.php?species_id=34 ). Densities at Dolly Sods, West Virginia, reached a high of 0.7 individuals/ha, and densities in eastern Tennessee reached 0.8 individuals/ha (Laseter 1999). In the Great Smoky Mountains National Park, on the Tennessee side, only three records exist and none have been recorded since 1960.
range:
The Appalachian Cottontail occurs in discontinuous upland patches (commonly 570-1,300 m, but with one report as low as 274 m) in the eastern United States including central Pennsylvania, western Maryland, western Virginia, eastern West Virginia, eastern Tennessee, eastern Kentucky, western North Carolina, northwestern South Carolina, northern Georgia, and northern Alabama including along the Interior Low Plateau (Whitaker and Hamilton 1998, Campbell et al. 2010).

The type locality is Dolly Sods, West Virginia (Tucker and Grant counties) in Monongahela National Forest, which is an important source population.
useTrade: The species is hunted for sport, meat, and fur.
conservationActions:
Conservation measures proposed to prevent the decline of the Appalachian Cottontail include:
  1. Conservation of critical habitat and establishment and management of “Important Mammal Areas” (as in Pennsylvania) containing known populations, with appropriate publicity and public education programs.
  2. Additional surveying and population monitoring.
  3. Research on nest sites, dispersal, habitat, use of corridors, response to climactic change and stochastic events, effects of sport hunting, competition with other lagomorphs (i.e. Eastern Cottontail and Snowshoe Hare), and response to invasive vegetative species.
  4. Development and implementation of state management plans.
  5. Public education and awareness programs, particularly to educate the sportsmen public about the habitats that the Appalachian Cottontail favors, to distinguish from the habitat that the game species Eastern Cottontails prefer, as the two species are easily confused (Chapman 1999).

rationale: The Brush Rabbit is abundant throughout most of its range, and most populations do not appear to be experiencing significant decline (Chapman and Ceballos 1990).The subspecies S. b. riparius has been listed as an endangered species by the state of California, USA (State of California 1994) and the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (Williams et al. 2004) due to decline primarily caused by habitat degradation, wildfire, and flood (Kelly 2018a,b). Additionally, three Mexican forms appear to be at risk: 1) S. b. exiguus is considered threatened and in need of immediate conservation actions, its current situation is unknown and it is probably extinct (Lorenzo et al. 2013); 2) it is possible that the southern form S. b. peninsularis may be extinct due to anthropogenic activities (Lorenzo et al. 2013); and 3) S. b. cerrosensis from Cedros Island, off the west coast of Baja California Sur is under intense pressure from predation by feral dogs, it is listed in danger of extinction in the Official Norm NOM-059 of Mexico (SEMARNAT 2010, Cortés-Calva el al. 2013, Lorenzo et al. 2014, Lorenzo-Monterrubio et al. 2018, Álvarez-Castañeda and Lorenzo 2016).
habitat:
The Brush Rabbit requires dense brush cover, occupying disjunctive bramble clumps, with the size of the clumps affecting home range size and suitability for occupation (Chapman 1974). Home ranges are small (less than 2,000 m2) and are dependent upon habitat uniformity (Chapman and Ceballos 1990). The bramble habitat contains runways and occasionally burrows formed by other species (Chapman and Ceballos 1990). Their diet consists predominantly of grasses, but it will consume alternative vegetation when seasonally available (Chapman 1974).

The breeding season for the Brush Rabbit varies from north to south, but appears to be uniform in length (Chapman 1974). In California, the species breeds from December to May or June, and in Oregon between February and August (Chapman and Ceballos 1990). Litter size varies regionally, with an annual mean of 2.87 in Oregon, 3.50 in north and central California, and 4.00 in west-central California (Chapman 1974). Fecundity of the Brush Rabbit is lower than other Sylvilagus species, producing about 15 young annually (Chapman 1974). Gestation time is approximately 27 days (Cervantes et al. 2005).

The subspecies S. b. riparius occupies both old-growth riparian forest, dominated by Valley Oak (Quercus lobata) and riparian communities dominated by thickets of willows (Salix spp.), wild roses (Rosa spp.), blackberries (Rubus spp.), and other successional trees and shrubs and when available dense tall stands of herbaceous plants adjacent to patches of riparian shrubs in the northern San Joaquin Valley, California. S. b. riparius stays close to dense stands of vegetation into which it retreats for escape, resting and nesting. They do not normally burrow or use burrows (Williams and Basey 1986, Williams 1988, Williams and Hamilton 2002). S. b. riparius eats a great variety of woody and herbaceous plants, preferring green foliage of shrubs, grasses and forbs. Much of its foraging is concentrated at the edge between thickets of woody plants and more open ground with herbaceous plants. A favored habitat is willow thickets along stream banks (Orr 1940, Chapman 1974, Kelt et al. 2014).

The area of highest abundance of the Cedros Island Brush Rabbit, S. b. cerrosensis is characterized by xeric scrubland vegetation with dominance of chamizo (Atriplex spp.), in association with sacrocaule and coastal desert scrub in the southwest part of the island composed by Limberbush (Jatropha cuneata), Oregano (Lippia palmeri), Fourwing Saltbush (Atriplex canescens), agaves (Agave shawii, A. sebastiana) and other shrubs (Lorenzo et al. 2014, Lorenzo-Monterrubio et al. 2018). S. b. cerrosensis shares its habitat with other endemic mammals, such as the San Diego Pocket Mouse (Chaetodipus fallax anthonyi), Bryant’s Woodrat (Neotoma bryanti bryanti), the Cedros Island Cactus Mouse (Peromyscus fraterculus cedrosensis), and Cedros Island Mule Deer (Odocoileus hemionus cerrosensis) (Lorenzo et al. 2014, Lorenzo-Monterrubio et al. 2018).

All the records of S. bachmani south of 30°N, not including the insular population (Cedros Island) are associated with mesic vegetation habitats, some of which are oases (Cervantes et al. 1999, Lorenzo et al. 2013).
threats:
Hunting for food and the clearing of land for human settlements pose a threat to Brush Rabbits, but the extent and severity are not quantified (but see select Mexican subspecies below).

Decline in numbers and threats of extinction of subspecies S. b. riparius stem principally from actions involved in developments of irrigated agriculture in the San Joaquin Valley of California. Foremost of these developments were stream impoundment, channelization of streams on the valley floor and the San Joaquin River Delta, and clearing and cultivation of natural communities. Riparian communities in the San Joaquin Valley have been reduced to about 1% of their historical extent, are found almost entirely within the levees of channelized streams. Most existing patches have been extensively degraded by wood cutting, livestock, invasion of exotic species, greater levels of flooding within levees, and lack of natural riverine processes (U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service 1998, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service 2000).

Principal existing threats to S. b. riparius can be summarized in order of importance as: 1) stochastic environmental processes, wildfire and flood; 2) additional habitat loss and degradation due to urbanization and conversion to agriculture; 3) increased predation from domestic and feral cats and dogs due to urban development adjacent to existing inhabited sites; and 4) genetic and demographic stochasticity in small populations. While all of these are proximate threats, wildfire and flood are probably the most severe threats to the population at Caswell MSP. A less imminent threat is natural successional processes that are reducing habitat quality. Because the park has multiuse objectives, and because up-stream impoundments have greatly modified the natural flooding regime, secondary successional patches, especially those caused by scouring floods, are disappearing from the Park. The changes are noticeable and may be associated with the decline in S. b. riparius within the park (Williams and Hamilton 2002).

For the South Delta metapopulation of S. b. riparius, wildfire is a serious threat to each subpopulation, but would unlikely affect all subpopulations simultaneously. Flooding poses a more immediate metapopulation threat, because the entire area is approximately at sea level or below, rivers are channelized, and there are few or no refugia above flood level. Over the past several decades there have been numerous breaks in levees and widespread flooding. The most recent were in 1997, 2006, and 2011. Typically, the only areas not flooded are built-up areas for railroads, levee tops, multilane highways and other developed sites. Likely these areas will be inundated at some time in the future when flooding is greater than it has been in recent decades. Urbanization also is viewed as an imminent threat because most of the known populations are adjacent to areas undergoing development planning, with construction slated to begin within 1-10 years. However, this threat may be mitigated by appropriate design and management of conservation lands set aside for Brush Rabbits and other organisms (Williams and Hamilton 2002).

The re-introduced population on the San Joaquin River NWR, like the populations at Caswell MSP and South Delta, is threatened by wildfire and flood, but major conservation actions to mitigate impacts of the flooding have been implemented at the refuge. See below.

S. b. cerrosensis from Cedros Island, off the west coast of Baja California Sur is under intense pressure from predation by feral dogs (Cortes-Calva et al. 2013, Álvarez-Castañeda and Lorenzo 2016). On Cedros Island there is a population of 2,696 inhabitants, whose main activity is obtaining salt from the salt flats of Guerrero Negro (INEGI 2010). There are vast areas covered with organic (lobster shells) and inorganic (glass bottles, metal material) garbage. Additionally, feral cats (Felis sylvestris) and feral dogs (Canis lupus) in large numbers occupy also the habitat where S. b. cerrosensis occurs. S. b. cerrosensis was abundant about 20 years ago, however poaching has been excessive and reduced the rabbit population to a situation that is currently critical (Lorenzo et al. 2014).

S. b. peninsularis may be extinct or close to extinct due to anthropogenic activities – the widespread building of infrastructure to support a growing tourist industry, using all the water of the river for the urban development, creating more desert areas in which the Desert Cottontail (Sylvilagus audubonii) is more common (Lorenzo et al. 2013).

S. b. exiguus from the central desert of the Baja California peninsula has always been rare and now may be declining due the process of desertification in the peninsula, in which the mesic environment has been more optimal for desert species such as the Desert Cottontail and Black-tailed Jackrabbit (Lepus californicus).
population:
Except for the Riparian Brush Rabbit (subspecies riparius) which is state (California) and federally listed as endangered (Williams et al. 2004), and the forms S. b. cerrosensis on Cedros Island, and S. b. exiguus and S. b. peninsularis on the Baja California peninsula, the Brush Rabbit is considered common where it is known to exist, throughout Oregon, California, and Baja California (Chapman and Ceballos 1990, Kelly 2018a).

The S. b. riparius population at Caswell Memorial State Park in San Joaquin County, California, USA, was statistically estimated in 1993, when there were 241 rabbits (approximate 95% confidence interval = 170-608) (Williams 1993). Similar censuses were conducted in 1997-2004, resulting in capture of 0 (1997) to 16 (2002) rabbits. Capture rates in the best year (2002) were only 27% of that of 1993, and captures and recaptures were too few in any one year since 1993 to use capture-recapture population models to meaningfully estimate population size (Williams et al. 2004).

Population censuses for the S. b. riparius South Delta metapopulation have not been conducted because of restrictions on activities on private land. However, capture rates for short-term assessments of presence and to capture breeders for a controlled propagation program suggested that this metapopulation have remained at fairly high densities since its discovery in 1998. Capture rates for the South Delta metapopulation varied from 127% to 626% of the capture rate of the Caswell MSP population in 1993. The South Delta population probably consists of about 300-600 rabbits at peaks in population cycles).

Censuses have also not been conducted for the re-introduced population of S. b. riparius on the San Joaquin River National Wildlife Refuge. However, visual and camera surveys suggest that the population is quite robust and now reaches into the thousands when conditions are optimal—due to the quality and quantity of available habitat.

In 2012 the population density of S. b. cerrosensis was estimated to be 1.21 individuals/km² and the number of individuals estimated as 145 in an area of 120.7 km² (Lorenzo et al. 2014).
range:
The Brush Rabbit is distributed along the Pacific coast of North America. It reaches the Columbia River in the north (Oregon-Washington border) and in the south it extends to the southern tip of Baja California. It extends east from the Pacific Ocean to the western Sierra Nevada mountain range (Chapman 1974, Kelly 2018). It occupies an elevational range of 0-2,070 m (Chapman 1974).

The subspecies S. b. riparius occurs only in Caswell Memorial State Park (MSP) on the Stanislaus River, and the South Delta area of the San Joaquin River, including Paradise Cut and Tom Paine Slough. The park size is 253 acres, and population on the South Delta occurs on privately owned land (Williams and Hamilton 2002). Even though there is other ideal habitat for S. b. riparius in MSP, they are unable to reach it because there is no connecting habitat above flood level in MSP (Sandoval, Williams, and Colliver 2006).

In Caswell Memorial State Park, Stanislaus River, San Joaquin County, California, USA, S. b. riparius occurs in about 90% of the park's 102 ha when populations are high, but about 20-40% of the Park at other times (Williams 1988, 1993).

The South Delta population of S. b. riparius, in the vicinity of Mossdale and Lathrop, San Joaquin County, CA, USA, exists on about 122 ha of private land within an area of about 2,927 ha. Populations are found along Paradise Cut, Tom Paine Slough, Grantline Canal, and the San Joaquin River. Rabbits also are found along the narrow right-of-ways of two railroads running through the area. Habitat for S. b. riparius is distributed in discontinuous, narrow strands of riparian vegetation along streams, sloughs, and railroad beds adjacent to intensely cultivated fields. Most land in this area is planned for urban and industrial development within the next 1-10 years. Existing habitat is periodically cut or burned for weed and flood control (Williams and Hamilton 2002).

The re-introduced population of S. b. riparius is located in the San Joaquin River National Wildlife Refuge in Stanislaus County, California. This refuge has about 285 ha of habitat for Brush Rabbits. An additional few hundred hectares have been restored from cropland to natural, riparian vegetation. Refugia from flooding, vegetated mounds and berms, have also been established throughout the refuge for rabbits and other terrestrial wildlife (Kelly 2018a, b).

The former range of S. b. peninsularis was from the Magdalena Bay region to the tip of the Baja California peninsula, although specimens are known only from two localities, Santa Anita and Cabo San Lucas separated by only 32 km. Recent intensive field work failed to locate any of the rabbits, and the area has been severely modified by tourist developments. The last known specimens of this subspecies were obtained only in the first quarter of the 20th century (Lorenzo et al. 2013).

The range of S. b. exiguus is in the central desert of the Baja California peninsula, where it is known from only eight localities. While recent intensive surveys have found desert cottontail rabbits to be common, no Brush Rabbits were observed at these sites. While the region only exhibits low human impact, it nevertheless appears that the exiguus subspecies is of conservation concern (Lorenzo et al. 2013).

S. b. cerrosensis is restricted to lowlands of Cedros Island, Baja California on the Pacific-north coast of Mexico. Cedros Island is a “mountain in the sea” so less than the 15% of the island is optimal habitat for S. b. cerrosensis, in addition with the presence of packs of feral dogs that in recent years have been controlled.
useTrade: This species is hunted for food and sport. <2-5% of the total  population is utilized, because their brushy preferred habitat is  unsuitable for hunting.
conservationActions:
There are no known conservation measures in place for the species as a whole.

The San Joaquin Valley population of subspecies S. b. riparius has been listed by the state of California as an endangered species (U. S. Fish and Wildlife Service 2000), and has been the subject of a recovery plan involving habitat management and captive breeding (U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service 1998, Kelly 2018b).

The following timeline includes recent conservation measures implemented for S. b. riparius:
1) Distribution and status review in 1986 (Williams and Basey 1986).
2) Listing as a California Species of Special Concern (Williams and Basey 1986).
3) Ecology and habitat management plan for Caswell Memorial State Park developed (Williams 1988).
4) Populations estimate made for Caswell MSP in 1993, the only known population at the time (Williams 1993).
5) Listed as an endangered species by the State of California in 1994 (State of California 1994).
6) Featured species in the multi-species Recovery Plan for Upland Species of the San Joaquin Valley, California (U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service 1998).
7) Habitat management plan focused on wildfire and flooding developed (Close and Williams 1998).
8) Listed as a USA endangered species by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service in 2002 (Williams et al. 2004).
9) Controlled Propagation and Reintroduction Plan for Riparian Brush Rabbits developed for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (Williams and Hamilton 2002).
10) Habitat acquisition and restoration begun by multi-agency CalFed Program with U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service as the land owner and manager, starting in 2000 and continuing to date (Williams et al. 2004).
11) Controlled propagation facility constructed beginning in 2001 and completed in 2002 by U.S. Bureau of Reclamation (Williams et al. 2004).
12) Controlled propagation of Riparian Brush Rabbits initiated in December 2001 with 3 males and 3 females in one large outdoor pen that contained semi-natural habitat conditions (Williams et al. 2004).
13) The re-introduced population of Riparian Brush Rabbits on the San Joaquin River NWR was started with the release of 49 young rabbits from the controlled propagation facility between July and October 2002 (Williams et al. 2004).
14) By the end of 2002, controlled propagation expanded to three breeding pens resulting in larger numbers of rabbits being released on the refuge, many fitted with radio-collars to get detailed information on survivorship, dispersal, and habitat use (Williams et al. 2008, Hamilton et al. 2010, Kelt et al. 2014).
15) Major spring flooding of the San Joaquin River in 2006 resulted in the mortality of nearly all Brush Rabbits on the refuge. The extent and severity of flooding was mapped so that locations could be chosen for the placement of large mounds of dirt that would be vegetated with brushy species and thereby serve as temporary refuges for rabbits during floods. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service also vegetated miles of bare river levees on the refuge with brushy species to provide additional upland cover for the rabbits (Kelly 2018b).
16) Major spring flooding of the San Joaquin River occurred again in 2011 and 2017, but because of the habitat management restoration measures taken following the 2006 flood, the population rebounded quickly in both years and despite high levels of flood-related mortality (Kelly 2018b).
17) In late 2005 and early 2006, rabbits were also released on the privately owned Faith Ranch, which is under conservation easement, and runs downriver along the San Joaquin River from the refuge boundary towards Caswell MSP. Later in 2006, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service acquired the Buffington property, which connects the Faith Ranch to Caswell MSP, thereby creating more than 20 continuous river-miles of riparian habitat for the Brush Rabbit (Kelly 2018b).
18) By the time the breeding and reintroduction program was suspended in December 2013, a total of 1,496 Riparian Brush Rabbits had been released on the refuge, that includes releases on the Faith Ranch and the Buffington property (Kelly 2018b).
19) The rabbit populations at Caswell MSP and on the San Joaquin River NWR continue to be monitored (Kelly 2018b).

Although S. b. cerrosensis is fully protected on Cedros Island, along with all native wildlife (SEMARNAT 2010), there is an urgent need to assess the pressures of habitat destruction and poaching on this subspecies. Cedros Island needs to correct its management of open industrial garbage dumps and to eradicate feral cats and dogs as soon as possible. The control of feral dogs began at the end of 1980 by personnel of the National Institute of Ecology in collaboration with local fishermen (McChesney and Tershy 1998), but the dogs were not eradicated because the effort was not constant. It is necessary to document the impact of exotic species of native fauna of Cedros Island. It is necessary to develop research projects to determine population dynamics, reproduction, ethology and other aspects of the biology and ecology of this subspecies (Lorenzo et al. 2014, Lorenzo-Monterrubio et al. 2018).

S. b. cerrosensis is an endangered subspecies according to the Official Norm NOM-059 of Mexico (SEMARNAT 2010). This subspecies has drastically declined because of habitat modification. The effort made to evaluate the status of this subspecies has been sufficient to consider it extinct.

S. b. exiguus is threatened. All these subspecies should be added to national and international lists of protected species (Lorenzo et al. 2013).

rationale: This species is confirmed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining at nearly the rate required to qualify for listing in a threatened category.
habitat:
Habitat preferences for Hewitt’s Red Rock Hare are considered similar to those of other Pronolagus species (Happold 2013). It prefers rocky hillsides and outcroppings, and "rock crevices and boulders are an essential component of the habitat" (Happold 2013). Where its range overlaps with Jameson’s Red Rock Hare (P. randensis), it occurs at higher elevations in areas that have fewer boulders and crevices and higher rainfall (Happold 2013). Habitat loss has been occurring over the last 100 years and is anticipated to continue to decline in total area by <20% over the next 20 years due to commercial plantations (Matthee et al. 2004).

While not much is known about the reproduction of this species, it is likely to be similar to other red rock hares. Breeding is restricted to warmer months during which time a female could produce three to four litters of one to two altricial (naked) young on each occasion (Matthee et al. 2016). Total length ranges from 38.0–53.5cm (Happold 2013).
threats: The main threat to rock hares is hunting, both for bushmeat and for  sport. Hunting pressure is thought to be more severe in areas of  high-density human settlements. For example in Lesotho, it is threatened  due to hunting pressure from herders with pack dogs (Lynch 1994).
